About.title: About us
About.description:
Nikolina Angelova, the Director of counselling Vitus Centre, is a qualified integrative counsellor with more than 8 years clinical experience. Nikolina uses an integrative approach which combines different psychological techniques to provide the best unique care for each individual approach. 

 Nikolina completed her MSc in Child and Adolescent Clinical Psychology at the University of Edinburgh, after which she specialised in Integrative Counselling. She is a counsellor member of the Scotland's professional body for counselling and psychotherapy (COSCA) and a qualified counselling supervisor by the Irish Association for Counselling and Psychotherapy (IACP). Nikolina is also an accredited counselling trainer and provides trainings for professionals in the caring professions.

 Her work specialises in trauma and bereavement, children and adolescence, attachment, relationship issues, emotionally focused therapy and creativity. Nikolina has a specific interest in working with traumatic experiences and working with the past, which began back in 2011. While she was studying Cultural and Social Anthropology at the University in Vienna, she also did a one-year course 'Introduction to Psychoanalysis'.  Research shows that creative approaches in counselling are extremely effective for self-exploration and in dealing with traumatic experiences and overcoming relationship crises.

VitusInfo.title: Vitus Centre
VitusInfo.description: Vitus Centre offers individual and family counselling, as well as supervision and trainings for professionals from the helping professions. Our counsellors are trained in the integrative approach- they combine different psychological techniques, in order to provide the best and unique care for each individual. Vitus Centre partners with international organisations, such as ‘Vital Connexions’ (Scotland), ‘Care4You’ (The Netherlands), to exchange therapeutic and training experience.

Vision.title: Our Vision
Vision.description:
We believe that every person is valuable and has a unique contribution to the welfare of society. Therefore, one of our main goals is to support each individual to overcome and to cope with life crises and difficulties, as well as traumatic experiences, and develop psychological resilience, in order to reach their full potential.

We chose the tree as a metaphor for humans, which if planted by streams of water (safe and supporting environment), will yield its fruit in season, its leaves will not wither, and in all that it does, it will prosper.

individualCounselling.title: Individual Counselling

familyCounselling.title: Family Counselling
familyCounselling.description: Vitus Centre offers family counselling, which includes all family members from a core family - parents and children. The aim of family counselling is to improve relationships and resolve conflicts within the family structure by working with all involved rather than individual clients to enhance communication, resolve conflict, and support families facing challenges.

couplesCounselling.title: Couples Counselling
couplesCounselling.description: Vitus Centre offers counselling for couples to help them understand and resolve conflicts in a healthy way. The emotionally focused therapy we use in couples counselling is evidence-based and equips each partner with tools to communicate with more empathy and less fear. It aids couples in feeling more emotionally connected and bonded with one another.

supervision.title: Supervision
supervision.description:
Vitus Centre offers individual and group supervision to professionals in the supporting professions such as psychologists, counsellors, and social workers. Supervision aims to support practitioners through the discussion of cases from their clinical practice. Supervision assists the individual professional and/or the team of professionals, on the one hand, in better understanding and recognising problematic areas in service users  and, on the other, in building a sustainable interaction among the professionals. In addition, it creates conditions for awareness of one's own behaviour in the profession and the associated feelings, as well as inspires motivation for positive change.

The experts at Vitus Centre have extensive experience in conducting individual and group supervision. They are trained to use the Cyclical model of supervision developed by Steve Page and Val Wosket, as well as the Process model of supervision developed by Peter Hawkins and Robin Shohet.

russianDolls.title: The Use of Russian Dolls in Counselling
russianDolls.description: In this practical training for professionals you will learn how to use Russian dolls as a creative approach in counselling. Using Russian dolls in counselling facilitates the counselling process by helping the client through projection to explore and overcome their emotional problems, stemming from past traumas and childhood experiences, and as a result to build a more holistic and sustainable self-image.

sandTrays.title: The Use of Sand Trays in Counselling
sandTrays.description: This training for professionals introduces different techniques and the benefits of using sand trays in counselling. Working with sand trays in counselling can powerfully enhance a client’s awareness of self and promote expression, exploration, and resolution of personal and interpersonal conflicts. The training is suitable for counsellors and social workers who would like to diversify and enrich their therapeutic approach.

clientsCreativity.title: Unleash Your Clients’ Creativity
clientsCreativity.description: This training provides an opportunity for professionals to experiment with a wide variety of creative approaches and to gain confidence in using them in counselling and social work.  The application of creative approaches in counselling has proven effective in helping the client resolve personal and interpersonal problems, express and know themselves better, and in deepening or focusing the therapeutic process.

couplesSeminar.title: “Hold me tight” - A seminar for couples
couplesSeminar.description: “Hold me tight” is an evidence-based programme, effective in improving couples' communication and relationships, and helping partners overcome crises and divisions in marital relations. It is based on emotionally focused therapy. More specifically, this program is aimed at helping couples discover and address negative dynamics that lead to feeling disconnected, hurt, and alone; understand and voice feelings and needs in ways that bring them closer to each other; begin to repair past hurts and injuries; strengthen or rebuild the trust between each other; renew the strength of their emotional connection; and strengthen bonding through physical affection and sex.
